column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#Text=enormous tropical forests, little known to man,
#Text=and from which he gathers here and there the treasures for
#Text=our orchid- and greenhouses ; great island conservatories like
#Text=Java and Ceylon and Borneo, rich in spices and lovely plant
#Text=life : Australian Bush, with traces of plant life as if from
#Text=\tanother world, but often most delicate in odour even in the
#Text=fragments of them we see in our greenhouses.
#Text=It is not only from the fragile flower-vases these sweet
#Text=odours flow; they breathe through leaf and stem, and the
#Text=whole being of many trees and bushes, from the stately
#Text=Cum trees of Australia to the sweet Verbena of Chili.
#Text=Many
#Text=must have felt the charm of the strange scent of the Boxbush before Oliver Wendell Holmes told us of its ‘ breathing
#Text=the fragrance of eternity, for this is one of the odours which
#Text=carry us out of time into the abysses of the unbeginning
#Text=past.’
#Text=The scent of flowers is often cloying, as of the
#Text=Tuberose, while that of leaves is often delightful and refreshing, as in the green budding Larch, and in the leaves of Balm
#Text=and Rosemary, while in many cases fragrance is stored in the
#Text=wood and permeates down through the roots.
#Text=To but few it is given to see many of these sweet plants
#Text=in their native lands, but we who love our gardens may
#Text=enjoy many of them about us, not merely in drawings or
#Text=descriptions, but the living, breathing things themselves.
#Text=The Geraniums in the cottage window bring us the spicy
#Text=\tfragrance of the South African hills ; the Lavender bush of
#Text=the sunny hills of Provence, where it is at home ; the
#Text=Roses in the garden bring near us the breath of the wild
#Text=Roses on a thousand hills ; the aromatic pot-herbs of our
#Text=gardens are a gift of the shore-lands of France and Italy and
#Text=Greece.
#Text=The Sweet Bay bush in the farmer’s or cottage
#Text=garden comes with its story from the streams of Greece,
#Text=where it seeks moisture in a thirsty land along with the wild
#Text=Olive and the Arbutus.
#Text=And this Sweet Bay is the Laurel
#Text=of the poets, of the first and greatest of all poet and artist
#Text=nations of the earth — the Laurel sacred to Apollo, and
#Text=used in many ways in his worship, as we may see on coins,
#Text=and in many other things that remain to us of the great
#Text=civilisations of the past . 1 The Myrtle, of less fame, was
#Text=also a sacred plant beloved for its leaves and blossoms, was,
#Text=like the Laurel, seen near the temples of the race who
#Text=built their temples as Lilies are built, whose song is deathless,
#Text=and the fragments of its art Despair to the artist of our
#Text=time.
#Text=And so we see how the fragrant bushes our gardens
#Text=may entwine for us, apart from their gift of fragrance, living
#Text=\tassociations and beautiful thoughts for ever famous in human
#Text=story.
#Text=It is not only these trees and climbers, loved by all for
#Text=their odour, we have to think of, but many delicate ones,
#Text=
#Text=1 ‘ What you call advantageous, Solon, is for these men to be
#Text=crowned in view of all the world, who just before were objects of pity
#Text=from their wounds : and yet it seems they think themselves happy if
#Text=in return for all their labours they can get a bunch of Laurel .’ — From
#Text=the Greek of Lucian.
#Text=little thought of, perhaps, from the blossoms that give it
#Text=being without showy colour, as the fragrant American wild
#Text=Vine.
#Text=And among these modest flowers there are none more
#Text=delicate than the blossoms of the White Willow of Britain
#Text=and northern Europe, all the more grateful in air coming
#Text=to us. ‘ O’er the northern moorland, o’er the northern foam. ’
#Text=
#Text=What is the lesson these sweet flowers have for us 1 They
#Text=tell us — if there were no other flowers to tell us — that a
#Text=\tgarden should be a living thing; its life not only fair in
#Text=form and lovely in colour, but in its breath and essence
#Text=coming from the Divine.
#Text=They tell us that the very common attempt to conform these fair lives into tile or other
#Text=patterns, to clip or set them out as so much mere colour
#Text=of the paper-stainer or carpet-maker, is to degrade them, and
#Text=make our gardens ugly and ridiculous, from the point of
#Text=view of nature or true art.
#Text=And many of these treasures for
#Text=the open garden have been shut out of our thoughts owing
#Text=to exclusion of almost everything that did not make showy
#Text=colour and lend itself to carpet or other crude modes of
#Text=setting flowers to compete with tiles and like modes of
#Text=‘ decoration.’
#Text=Of the many considerations that should occur in the
#Text=making of a beautiful garden to live in, this of fragrant
#Text=plants and flowers is one of the first.
#Text=And happily among
#Text=every class of flowers which adorn our open-air gardens,
#Text=there are odorous things to be found.
#Text=Apart from the
#Text=groups of plants in which all, or nearly all, are sweet, as
#Text=in Roses and Violets, the annual and biennial flowers of
#Text=\tour gardens, are rich in fragrance, Stocks, Mignonette,
#Text=Sweet Peas, Sweet Sultan and Wallflowers, Double Rockets, Sweet Scabious, and many others, the odours of which are
#Text=not always so popular.
#Text=These, among the most easily raised
#Text=of plants, are enjoyed by the simplest cottage gardeners.
#Text=The garden borders bear for us odours as precious as
#Text=any breath of tropic Orchid : from the Lily of the Valley
#Text=to the Carnation — this last being perhaps the most grateful
#Text=odour of all the flowering host in our garden land.
#Text=Among
#Text=these borders one meets with things sweeter than words may
#Text=tell of — Woodruff, Balm, Pinks, Violets, garden Primroses,
#Text=Polyanthus, day and other Lilies, early Iris, Narcissus,
#Text=evening Primroses, Mezereon Bush, Wallflower and Pansies,
#Text=delicate in their sweetness.
#Text=No one may be richer in delicate fragrance than the wise
#Text=man who plants hardy shrubs and flowering trees — Magnolia, Thorn, Daphne, Lilac — names each telling of whole
#Text=families of delightful things.
#Text=Among shrubs, those without
#Text=any very strong odour, like the hardy Heaths, are all the
#Text=more pleasant to many whose memories are often touched
#Text=\tby remembered fragrance of some plant they do not always
#Text=know.
#Text=From the same regions where we found the Laurel
#Text=and the Myrtle we have the Laurustinus, beautiful in all
#Text=our sea-coast and milder districts, and many other lovely
#Text=things happy in our climate : one, the Winter Sweet, even
#Text=pouring out delicious fragrance in mid-winter : Sweet Gale,
#Text=that grows in any boggy place, Azalea, Allspice, and the
#Text=delightful little Mayflower that creeps about in the woodland shades in North America.
#Text=So, though we cannot boast
#Text=N of Lemon or Orange groves, our climate is kind to many
#Text=lovely and fragrant shrubs.
#Text=Even our ugly walls may be sweet gardens with Magnolia,
#Text=Honeysuckle, Clematis, Sweet Verbena, and the delightful
#Text=old Jasmine, still clothing many a house in London.
#Text=Most
#Text=precious of all, however, are the noble climbing Tea Roses
#Text=raised in our own time, mostly in France within the past
#Text=forty years or so.
#Text=Among the abortions of this century
#Text=these are a real gain — the loveliest flowers ever raised by
#Text=man.
#Text=Noble in form and colour, and scented as delicately
#Text=as a J une morn in alpine pastures, with these most precious
#Text=\tof garden roses we could cover all the ugly walls in England and Ireland, and Heaven knows there are many in want
#Text=of a veil.
#Text=The old Kent and Sussex way of having an orchard near
#Text=the house was a good one.
#Text=Planted for use, it was as precious
#Text=for its beauty, and not only when the spring winds carry
#Text=the breath of its myriad blossoms of Cherry, Plum, Apple,
#Text=or Pear.
#Text=We have the fruit odours too, and the faint scent
#Text=of Strawberries, and later their leaves, and the Currant leaves.
#Text=It would be, in many places, charming to plant a pretty
#Text=orchard and have the fruit-garden near or alongside — keeping the less pleasant evidence of vegetables in the background.
#Text=These beautiful orchards, too, are where the early Daffodils
#Text=and Snowdrops appear.
#Text=Then, with Violets and Primroses
#Text=on the banks they may be delightfully sheltered from the
#Text=north and east by a grove of our native evergreens — Holly
#Text=and Yew — these, in their turn, wreathed here and there
#Text=with the fragrant autumn Clematis, Honeysuckles, and
#Text=Climbing Wild Roses.
#Text=Of all the things for garden pictures
#Text=there are none so good as the lovely groups of hardy trees
#Text=forming our hardy fruits, including the Medlar and Quince,
#Text=while near might be the Japanese and other handsome Crabs,
#Text=which have so much beauty of bloom and also brilliant fruit
#Text=in autumn.
#Text=MONO the many enjoyments this fascinating
#Text=world affords, none are more innocent or
#Text=enticing than close association with the
#Text=beautiful gems that so happily grace our
#Text=gardens, where a balmy atmosphere laden
#Text=with sweet perfumes and aromatic fragrance, rich and embowering foliage, with rural seclusion, are ever perfect ideas
#Text=of earthly felicity —
#Text=
#Text=‘ In the calm retreat,
#Text=
#Text=Far from the busy haunts of life,
#Text=
#Text=Where Flora trains her lovely offspring up
#Text=To captivate and charm.’
#Text=In all countries, civilised and savage, in the religious festivals
#Text=of all creeds, and on all occasions whether of grief or rejoicing, the scented attractions of flowers and plants possess an
#Text=important significance, and Nature seems to have been most
#Text=bountiful in her munificence in scattering these odoriferous
#Text=treasures throughout our world, to give cheerfulness to the
#Text=earth and happiness to its inhabitants.
#Text=Every rank of people
#Text=seem equally to appreciate them as a gratification to the
#Text=organs of sight and smell.
#Text=The refreshing odours prevalent in a garden, where the richest
#Text=perfumes shed their aromatic perfections lavishly around, are
#Text=the spoils from Nature’s laboratory, that dispense delicious
#Text=medicines to sweeten our existence.
#Text=There are many common flowers to be found growing in
#Text=our meadows which diffuse a gentle fragrance most gratifying
#Text=to the senses : and, much as we are concerned with the odour
#Text=of those flowers and shrubs which are to be met with in our
#Text=gardens and greenhouses, the wild forms are a source of the
#Text=keenest pleasure to all.
